snippet: In Greenwich, Conn., as well as in other high-performing public school districts, administrators are resorting to surprise home visits and legal affidavits to ensure students live in the district.
abstract: Greenwich, Conn, public schools, in an effort to weed out nonresidents, now require parents or guardians registering children for school to complete notarized affidavits confirming they live within the boundaries of the district; problem exists in towns and cities with high-performing school districts and tightening budgets; school districts want to ensure that shrinking budgets are not being spent on students whose families may be tricking the system to get a better education.

byline.original: By JENNY ANDERSON and KRISTIN HUSSEY

lead_paragraph: In Greenwich, Conn., as well as in other high-performing public school districts, administrators are resorting to surprise home visits and legal affidavits to ensure students live in the district.

headline.seo: Standing Guard Against Education Thieves at Coveted Schools
headline.main: Schools Look to Weed Out Nonresidents
headline.print_headline: Schools Look to Weed Out Nonresidents
